A very brilliant movie which manages to keep you engrossed throughout every minute. The stellar performances makes it very difficult to wholly dislike even the worst characters (does the fact that they're all supposedly holy men help in this regard?) The movie drops many crumbs early on which makes it clear that *something* will happen with x and y, but each one is paid off in very rewarding ways that would be difficult to expect. Cardinal Lawrence, played by Ralph Fiennes, gives what at times seems like an exceedingly amazing performance--it feels like scenes were added just to flex his amazing skills, despite not necessarily adding much to the character or story. I watched this without subtitles, which, with all the language switching that happens with certain characters, makes it somewhat difficult to follow at times. But the acting and delivery and structure of the scenes makes it clear to the watcher at least vaguely what's happening, even if the dialogue is unintelligible. The twist at the end, despite technically being set up, does feel like it came somewhat out of no where, but is rewarded anyways by an excellent performance by [spoiler]. It's a quiet yet thrilling political drama set in a restricted setting, and each action feels just as consequential as the last.

Having heard about Conclave since the announcement of the 2025 Oscar nominees, I must admit that I only got around to watching it after Pope Francis' death. And by the time the film was over, I could understand all the praise I had heard about it. The direction and photography are brilliant; the soundtrack is remarkable; and the cast is incredible, with Ralph Fiennes being a standout. Having watched it after Pope Francis' death and, therefore, before the conclave to elect the new Pope, this film touched me deeply. I simply loved the personalities of each cardinal, and the internal disputes between them: far from being gods, they are normal people, with dilemmas, fears and flaws. The settings are also another highlight, contributing entirely to the immersion in the story. A simple, yet brilliant film.

Really a waste of a lot of fine actors.

Conclave had all the makings of a great film ‚Äî a stellar cast, strong cinematography, and a fascinating premise ‚Äî but unfortunately, it didn‚Äôt quite deliver a satisfying experience from start to finish. While the acting was superb (Ralph Fiennes and John Lithgow were easily the highlights, delivering layered, memorable performances), the film‚Äôs structure left a lot to be desired. Over the course of two hours, Conclave introduced more questions than it answered, creating plot holes that were never fully addressed. Important storylines seemed to fizzle out, and some conclusions felt more like abrupt stops than true endings. It‚Äôs clear there was a lot of potential here, and at times, the film showed flashes of brilliance. But ultimately, the lack of narrative payoff made it feel incomplete ‚Äî like a beautifully set table with half the meal missing. Fans of Fiennes and Lithgow will still find something to appreciate, but Conclave falls short of being the thoughtful, gripping drama it could have been.

[SPOILDER ALERT...] Great acting, Interesting story... until the end. The ending and its climax felt absurd and artificially constructed, lacking authenticity and impact. The story would have been far more compelling with a dramatic twist‚Äîimagine Lawrence secretly orchestrating everything, pulling strings in the shadows only to ascend to the papacy himself. Or the sudden revelation that the Pope was murdered, shattering expectations and throwing the Vatican into chaos. Maybe Benitez, chosen as Pope, turns out to be an imposter, forcing Lawrence into an impossible moral dilemma‚Äîdoes he expose the deception or safeguard the Church from further scandal? Any of these would have deepened the intrigue, making the narrative richer and far more unpredictable, rather than relying on a biological revelation as the central twist.

Conclave is a historical fictional film about the ins-and-outs of running a conclave when a Pope dies. The film touches the surface of minor Politics involved in the decision for the next Holy Father, the dynamics of the conclave, all while following Cardinal Lawrence, his struggles with the Church, and his dedication to God. Heavy on drama, the story is slow-paced like a Conclave itself. The glimpses we get of the rites that happen during this period are cool for a particular audience, but the runtime might be a detractor for those who couldn‚Äôt care less. Though strong on its execution and great on the visuals, Conclave fails to shine a light onto the deeper aspects of a real conclave. The film shows little of the discussions and party rallies, and the major mystery is dismissed for much of the runway, swapped for a minor one that is easy to solve. When the major mystery comes back for the final revelation, the shocking it is supposed to entail is quickly wrapped up with an ending that leaves things too open. Conclave entertains those that have some sort of religious interest or belief, especially Catholics and close variants. Anyone that dismisses religion or really just can‚Äôt stand it, well, won‚Äôt stand this story either.

Upon the pope‚Äôs death, cardinal Lawrence (Ralph Fiennes) by virtue of position as dean, forms a conclave where cardinals are sequestered in the Vatican City, free from outside influence and submerged in secrecy to vote for a new pope. Ralph Fiennes succeeds in evoking a reluctant, worried but determined manager, a shepherd herding a flock of considerably, some of the most powerful men in the world. These men whisper and subtly malign their contemporaries‚Äô chances of getting voted into the papacy. On top of this, cardinal Lawrence deals with a crisis of faith, initially resolved not to listen to matters about backgrounds that may describe a candidate as unworthy, but his own morality defies this rule ‚Äì learning of past scandals and leading to revelations and disqualifications. On the other hand, this leads to him also becoming a suitable candidate by his peers, earning votes he claims he does not desire, earning both judgement and support. The film hints on the ongoing symptoms of institutions that abuse power and tolerates prejudice, championed by those who lead them. And some of this are embedded in laws that entail breaking to do what is right. The cardinals are framed not as caricatures of agendas but people of converging and contrasting beliefs. There are also no purely antagonistic forces but merely the clash of views leading to conflict. Far into the film, the audience is reminded of the power and influence this group of people hold as a bomb tears a hole into the church ceilings, fortunately failing to injure the cardinals. By the end, after a joust of words, the final voting sets a winner, with a twist reveal that tiptoes close to fiction yet not entirely impossible. Depending on audience belief, we are left to play out the remainder of the outcome, but are as relieved as cardinal Lawrence that the conclave is over.

There‚Äôs a kind of hush in Conclave‚Äînot silence, but the coiled, breath-held quiet of ancient ritual dressed in modern cutlery. It hums beneath cassocks and gritted teeth, beneath the Sistine ceiling that feels less like heaven and more like surveillance. This is a thriller measured in eye flickers and murmured allegiance, where every footstep echoes like a gavel against the ribs of God Himself. The film dares to strip theology of majesty and expose its scaffolding‚Äîfragile men with trembling hands attempting to steer the eternal. It is not about faith; it‚Äôs about the performance of belief, a kind of ecclesiastical LARP in the Vatican's bowels, where politics and power pirouette around a slowly dying candle. Fiennes walks like a man who‚Äôs been hollowed out by too many whispered truths. His performance isn‚Äôt acting, it‚Äôs a slow possession. You watch him dissolve into robes and ritual, until only guilt remains‚Äîdense and invisible as incense. His eyes do most of the speaking, which feels apt in a film where words are dangerous currency. But what I loved‚Äîwhat made this film throb with relevance‚Äîwas how it made the divine feel mundane, and the mundane feel profound. A key in a drawer has the tension of a loaded gun. A hallway becomes a confession. And when secrets slip through cracks, they don‚Äôt fall‚Äîthey metastasize. The final reveal is less twist and more transubstantiation. A quiet heresy buried in cloth and dust. And it asks‚Äînot whether men can speak for God‚Äîbut whether they've just been speaking to themselves, in a cathedral-sized echo chamber.

Edward Berger's film following the drama and intrigue of the secretive process of the Papal Conclave - the sequestered meeting in which a new pope is elected - is a masterclass in adaptation. Taking Robert Harris's novel as its source, what could have been claustrophobic becomes intimate and what could have been tortuous becomes suffused with low-key but no less gripping tension. Beautifully written and shot, it seems at first glance to be a long way from the director's previous film, his excellent take on All Quiet On The Western Front. But there are connections - both films are concerned with the machinery of their subject matter. War in the first instance, church politics. In both cases there is a different kind of tragedy showing starkly how human beings become part of that machinery - trying to do good, sucked up into the business of which they are a part, principles and humanity constantly up for debate as compromises are made, broken and remade. Both films focus on groups made up almost entirely of men - but certainly in Conclave, the role of women is cleverly noted - and when one woman intervenes it is economic and powerful. Brilliantly cast, there's some superbly subtle acting - especially in the way different performers employ there faces, reacting to what they see, hear or communicating wordlessly what they think and feel. The film's revelatory twist could have been tacky in other hands - but the film having built up an effective atmosphere of secrecy and claustrophobia, shutting out the outside the world, it works brilliantly. In my screening there were audible gasps and brief gaggle of excited chattering at the revelation. It's refreshing also that a piece of art can be clear about its criticisms of faith and the church specifically but still understand the importance of the role these things play in people's lives. Spirituality is understood, not patronised - which makes its critiques all the more powerful and its characters all the more humane. A superb, intelligent, gracious political thriller that will provoke as much thought as it grips and surprises.

Whilst the production quality is good, the story drags on a lot for such little happening. The spoiler free summaries lead you to believe that there's a more in-depth corruption scandal than there is, when it's minor and simple corruption, not relating to criminal behaviour. There are some heretical concepts pushed as normal and accepted concepts, which are not biblically sound, and it seems quite clear to me that it was done to push certain ideological viewpoints, so if you're looking to watch the movie from any sort of accuracy or educational standpoint, then you won't find that here. The ending plot twist was so absurd and out of pocket that I couldn't even be annoyed at it, it actually made me physically laugh, despite the intended tone of the scene. The only reason I wouldn't give it lower is because the cinematography is actually decent. I think ‚ÄúConclave‚Äù is beautifully intelligent. The audience can feel the tension inside the Sistine Chapel, the fear that other voters will elect the wrong cardinal to be the new Pope, the fear that they won‚Äôt follow the ideals and achievements of the former Pope. I have to say that the work of recreating the Sistine Chapel was incredible, the details‚Ä¶ in short, a good film with good acting and good direction. This film certainly deserved to win several Oscars, especially Best Picture, but in the hearts of the audience, Conclave will be the moral winner. I don't understand how a movie can feel both so monumental in terms of stakes and themes, yet so intimate and contained with regard to character and logistical scope. Someone needs to tell Edward Berger to chill, man, lol. This man is swiftly becoming one of the most impressive filmmakers working today and it's by no small margin. To pivot from the sobering, almost apocalyptic feelings brought about by "All Quiet On The Western Front" to the more cerebral and world-affirming stylings of "Conclave" is one thing -- but to make both feel as consequential and as thematically cathartic as the other (two completely different movies!) is just amazing talent at work. Impeccable acting here, too. Ralph Fiennes carries the weight of this on his whole frame and he deserves every award he's been nominated for, in my opinion. Though, everyone does such a damn good job in this, you could freakin' blink and surely miss a great performance from a background actor or something. A collection of objectively thought-provoking ethical case studies, strung together with brilliant storytelling, set against the backdrop of organized religion. . .AND it doesn't ultimately feel condescending to any particular group of people? One of the best films of this past year, hands down.

Conclave brings to light the political game involved in choosing a new pope, which can be easily compared to presidential elections, for example. Watching the excellent actor Ralph Fiennes lead the election of the pope shows that it is not an easy choice and that it has great weight for all Catholic Church faithful around the world. However, it ends up coming up against the personal dilemmas of each candidate and shows how human beings put their own interests first. At first, it may seem like a criticism of the Catholic Church, but on the contrary, it wants to show that, despite the adversities, the church remains firm and its ideals intact. It is not a film with a surprising and action-packed story, but it keeps the audience's expectations high with each vote. Rooting for Ralph Fiennes' character becomes the easiest path, but the film gives us an ending that is above that.

It is essential to clarify that the movie Conclave is NOT a faithful representation of reality; rather, it is a work of fiction based on a novel, with invented characters designed to create a dramatic thriller. Due to its serious and detailed tone, along with the lack of explicit clarifications regarding its fictional nature, the film can contribute to misinformation if viewers believe it accurately reflects how the Church operates. Conclave presents a distorted view of the Church and the Vatican as a place of dark secrets and conspiracies, diverging from its true function as the spiritual and administrative center of the Catholic Church. Cardinals are portrayed as excessively ambitious figures, focused on power struggles and morally questionable behavior, reinforcing a stereotypical and negative image of the clergy. Let‚Äôs clarify some points depicted in the film: The conclave process is not merely an electoral event but a profoundly spiritual occasion. Cardinals seek to discern God‚Äôs will through prayer, reflection, and deliberation. Certain plot elements contradict official Church teachings and established practices, which may lead to confusion. Some viewers might mistakenly believe that the Church is open to elections or practices that are currently not possible under its doctrine. The film portrays the conclave as an event where extraordinary situations can easily occur, whereas in reality, it is strictly regulated by detailed norms and traditions rooted in deep reforms. The audience may interpret that the Catholic Church is more divided, disorganized, or flexible in its doctrines than it actually is, reinforcing misconceptions and stereotypes. The movie presents a one-sided and overly pessimistic view of the Church, ignoring the many examples of service, charity, and holiness that exist in reality. It is important to distinguish between the fictional elements of the film and the real principles that govern the Catholic Church. While Conclave presents an intriguing scenario from a narrative perspective, it significantly deviates from doctrinal reality and the practical criteria that guide the Church‚Äôs leadership.

The film pulls you straight into the Vatican, with stunningly authentic sets that make you feel like you're actually there. The dialogue crackles with intelligence, every exchange layered with intrigue, power struggles, and hidden motives. And that soundtrack‚Äîsubtle yet haunting‚Äîperfectly underscores the weight of every whispered conversation. Just when you think you know where it‚Äôs going, the film throws in a twist that keeps you hooked. It‚Äôs no surprise this one‚Äôs racking up Oscar nominations. *Conclave* is proof that pure storytelling, when done right, can be just as thrilling as any action-packed blockbuster. A well-earned four stars.

‚ÄúConclave,‚Äù directed by Edward Berger and released on October 25, 2024, offers a behind-the-scenes look at the secretive process of electing a new pope following the sudden death of the incumbent. The film boasts a stellar cast, including Ralph Fiennes as Cardinal Thomas Lawrence, Stanley Tucci as Cardinal Bellini, and John Lithgow as Cardinal Tremblay. Ôøº The narrative centers on Cardinal Lawrence, who is tasked with overseeing the conclave. As the cardinals gather, political maneuvering and personal ambitions come to the forefront, revealing a web of intrigue within the Vatican‚Äôs hallowed halls. The film delves into themes of faith, power, and the complexities of religious leadership. The musical score by Volker Bertelmann and the cinematography by St√©phane Fontaine are standout elements, creating a visually stunning and sonically rich experience. However, there are moments where the dramatic emphasis in the score and visuals seems to surpass the narrative‚Äôs intensity, potentially overshadowing the story‚Äôs subtler aspects. Performances by Fiennes and Tucci are commendable, bringing depth and nuance to their roles. Despite the film‚Äôs buildup, the anticipated intense scandal culminates in a reveal that serves more as a commentary on contemporary political conservatism than a dramatic climax. While ‚ÄúConclave‚Äù has garnered critical attention, it may owe some of its prominence to a relatively subdued year in cinema. Overall, ‚ÄúConclave‚Äù is a thought-provoking film that offers insight into the clandestine world of papal elections, bolstered by strong performances and exceptional technical elements. However, its narrative choices may leave some viewers desiring a more impactful resolution.

With strong visuals and excellent performances, this film stands out as a meticulously crafted drama. The cast is superb, with Ralph Fiennes (outstanding), Stanley Tucci, and John Lithgow delivering layered, compelling performances. Isabella Rossellini, one of the few female figures in the film, brings her signature presence‚Äîmysterious, poised, and full of depth. Director Edward Berger demonstrates outstanding craftsmanship, proving once again that he understands how to shape both characters and audience emotions with precision. He skillfully manipulates tension and intrigue, making for an immersive experience. The film‚Äôs depiction of the Vatican‚Äôs inner world is fascinating, offering an insightful look into the highly exclusive and enigmatic world of the vatican. The story and script adaptation are masterfully crafted, maintaining depth and intrigue throughout‚Äîuntil the final moments. Unfortunately, the revelation of the new pope‚Äôs ‚Äúsecret‚Äù feels unnecessary and contrived, seemingly added to align with a contemporary political or cultural agenda rather than serving the film‚Äôs organic narrative. The inner conflict of the lead character (Ralph Fiennes) is already profoundly evident and beautifully developed, making this late twist feel artificial and redundant rather than enhancing the story. Of course you can add a "surprise" and deliver a message you think it is worth to be told, but in this case it was simply too much on the nose. Instead of deepening the film‚Äôs impact, it disrupts the carefully constructed world and risks undermining its resonance on the international stage. All at all, a visually stunning, exceptionally well-acted film with a gripping narrative and outstanding direction. Were it not for the forced final revelation, it could have been a true modern classic. Still, a must-watch for those who appreciate intelligent, atmospheric storytelling and superb performances.

Conclave is presented as a study that explores power relations, questioning the importance of truth and the role of leadership. Conclave is defined as a tense and satisfying drama, where individual interests and aspirations clash. It is a hilarious representation of power struggles, the meaning of truth and the relevance of certainties and doubts. However, in practical terms, it is a film that can be considered mostly forgettable. Conclave is more than a war of egos and ambitions. We are faced with a cinematographic work that is solid, serious, intelligent and visually attractive, but which is supported mainly by the performances, which are generally first class (a special mention for Isabella Rossellini) and by the surprising twists of the story, which are developed with intelligent and fun creativity. An ecclesiastical script, incredibly sharp, unexpected and with a message as risky as it is pertinent.

Conclave (2023), directed by Edward Berger and featuring an ensemble cast led by Ralph Fiennes, Stanley Tucci, and John Lithgow, is a gripping political thriller that immerses viewers in the secretive world of the Catholic Church. Based on Robert Harris‚Äôs novel, the film unfolds within the confines of the Sistine Chapel as a conclave of cardinals gathers to elect a new pope following the sudden death of the previous pontiff. Amidst the solemn rituals and cloaked traditions, personal rivalries and explosive secrets threaten to unravel the sanctity of the process. From the outset, Berger establishes a meticulously crafted atmosphere of tension and reverence. The first half of the film sets a deliberate pace, immersing the audience in the intricacies of the conclave and the subtle power plays between the cardinals. Fiennes delivers a masterclass in restraint as Cardinal Lomeli, the protagonist whose quiet demeanor belies a sharp intellect and moral resolve. The interplay between Fiennes and Tucci, portraying the cunning Cardinal Bellini, brims with understated intensity, while Lithgow‚Äôs Cardinal Tremblay injects a measure of gravitas and ambiguity into his performance. Berger‚Äôs direction shines in the film‚Äôs visual and auditory details. The cinematography by James Friend captures the grandeur and intimacy of the Vatican with equal finesse, utilizing soft lighting and rich textures to convey both the beauty of the setting and the weight of the decisions being made. Volker Bertelmann‚Äôs score underscores the narrative‚Äôs solemnity while subtly amplifying moments of suspense and revelation. The film‚Äôs editing complements its structure, allowing the tension to build methodically in the first half before propelling viewers into a more fast-paced and unpredictable second act. The screenplay, adapted by Harris himself, strikes a balance between theological discourse and human drama. The script avoids overwhelming viewers with jargon, instead focusing on the universal themes of power, faith, and redemption. The dialogues crackle with intelligence, particularly during heated debates between the cardinals, which expose the ideological divides within the Church. However, the narrative occasionally falters when it leans too heavily on exposition, particularly in the slower moments of the first act, which may test the patience of some viewers. The film‚Äôs second half takes an unexpected turn, shifting from a contemplative exploration of faith and duty into a high-stakes game of political intrigue. This dynamic shift is handled deftly, as Berger ramps up the tension and delivers a series of revelations that challenge the audience‚Äôs perceptions of the characters. The climactic moments are both shocking and thematically resonant, tying together the personal and political threads in a satisfying manner. One of the film‚Äôs greatest strengths lies in its ability to probe weighty questions without providing easy answers. It examines the tension between tradition and progress, as well as the fragility of human morality in the face of power. Comparisons to other ecclesiastical dramas like The Two Popes are inevitable, but where that film leaned on warmth and humor, Conclave opts for a darker, more introspective tone. Berger‚Äôs approach also recalls the taut storytelling of his earlier work in All Quiet on the Western Front, showcasing his knack for blending character-driven drama with broader thematic concerns. As awards season approaches, Conclave is generating considerable Oscar buzz, particularly for Fiennes‚Äôs nuanced performance and Berger‚Äôs assured direction. The film‚Äôs technical achievements, including its production design and score, are also strong contenders for recognition. While it may not appeal to audiences seeking fast-paced entertainment, those with an appreciation for intelligent, character-driven narratives will find much to admire in this meticulously crafted drama. Overall, Conclave earns four stars for its compelling performances, thoughtful storytelling, and striking visuals. It is a film that lingers in the mind long after the credits roll, inviting reflection on the complexities of faith, leadership, and the human condition. Whether you‚Äôre drawn to the intrigue of its premise or the depth of its themes, this is a cinematic experience well worth seeking out.

This mystery thriller directed by Edward Berger is based on the 2016 novel by Robert Harris, in which the Cardinal-Dean organises a papal conclave to elect the next pope and finds himself investigating secrets and scandals about each candidate at the center of a conspiracy that could shake the very foundation of the Catholic Church. A masterful and gripping film executed with the utmost care, with a career-defining performance by Ralph Fiennes imbued with depth and gravitas, a spellbinding cinematography that captures the grandeur and solemnity of the Vatican, a compelling screenplay full of surprising plot twists throughout until the very end, and an inspiring score composed by Volker Bertelmann. It is also reportedly a very accurate adaptation of the book it is based on, which should be an easy feat, given the straightforward development of the story. With its timely exploration of religion and controversial themes, this film is poised to join the ranks of the most relevant and thought-provoking dramas of our era. The ensemble cast truly shines, elevating an already incredible story into a cinematic masterpiece.

One of the first films of 2024 that I heard attracting awards buzz as the year drew to a close, Conclave demonstrates that films about somewhat mundane subject matter can be elevated with smart writing, excellent performances and a story that carefully meters out its information to keep you interested. Unlike something like Lincoln, where the script is so verbose you fell like you‚Äôre being beaten over the head with dialogue, in Conclave its much more pared back. Characters look like they‚Äôre actually considering what‚Äôs being said to them, and what they‚Äôre about to say in response. Ralph Fiennes plays a Cardinal whose careful and considered approach sees him earn the respect of many of his peers, but also the scorn of others, much like how the papal candidates differing points of view makes the voting process so unpredictable. One thing I really appreciate the film for its visual style. It would be so easy for a film of this subject matter to look flat and dull, but much has been done to give it flair and panache. A simple scene of Cardinals walking across a forecourt is rendered striking and memorable with the use of umbrellas and a high angle. Edward Berger is the same man who directed the excellent 2022 version of All Quiet on the Western Front, and this is another great addition to his filmography: Serious in subject matter but entertaining and accessible every step of the way.

‚ÄúConclave‚Äù is a masterfully crafted thriller that delves into the clandestine world of the Vatican, offering viewers a gripping portrayal of the papal election process. Directed by Edward Berger and based on Robert Harris‚Äôs 2016 novel, the film boasts a stellar ensemble cast, including Ralph Fiennes, Stanley Tucci, John Lithgow, and Isabella Rossellini. The narrative centers on Cardinal Thomas Lawrence (Ralph Fiennes), who is tasked with organizing a conclave to elect a new pope following the sudden death of the pontiff. As the cardinals convene, the film meticulously unravels the intricate political maneuvers, personal ambitions, and deep-seated secrets that influence the election process. Fiennes delivers a nuanced performance, capturing Cardinal Lawrence‚Äôs internal conflicts and moral dilemmas with remarkable depth. His portrayal has been lauded as ‚ÄúOscar-worthy,‚Äù with critics highlighting his ability to convey the character‚Äôs complexity and torment. Ôøº Stanley Tucci‚Äôs portrayal of Cardinal Aldo Bellini adds another layer of intrigue, with his character‚Äôs motivations and actions keeping audiences on edge. The film‚Äôs tension is further amplified by Volker Bertelmann‚Äôs evocative score, which complements the suspenseful atmosphere and the high-stakes environment of the conclave. Ôøº Critics have praised ‚ÄúConclave‚Äù for its intelligent screenplay by Peter Straughan, which balances the solemnity of the Vatican‚Äôs traditions with the human flaws of its characters. The film‚Äôs production design and cinematography are equally commendable, capturing the grandeur and secrecy of the Vatican with stunning visuals. The meticulous attention to detail immerses viewers in the sacred rituals and the opulent yet austere settings of the papal enclave. While the film delves into serious themes, it also offers moments of sharp dialogue and subtle humor, reflecting the complexities and contradictions within the Church‚Äôs hierarchy. The plot unfolds with deliberate pacing, leading to a climax that is both unexpected and thought-provoking, prompting viewers to reflect on the nature of faith, power, and human frailty. ‚ÄúConclave‚Äù is not just a film about religion; it‚Äôs a compelling exploration of the intersection between faith and politics, tradition and change. Its timely release and the themes it tackles resonate with contemporary discussions about institutional power and personal belief. For those seeking a film that combines suspense, stellar performances, and profound thematic depth, ‚ÄúConclave‚Äù is a must-watch.

Having today seen Chritianne Amanpour interview the director, Edward Berger, I said to my husband, "Yeah, let's pay Amazon $19.99 and watch it tonight." Tonight is the eve of erev Hanukah and Christmas, a gift to ourselves, this movie. Growing up Catholic I followed the news for each pope elected since John XXIII, so I knew the process. My old sense of yuck at the all male cast in their red dresses and gold jewelry, their arrogance and obliviousness turned me off at the beginning.. Why would Amanpour have had that reaction to what starts out looking like just another pretentious pope movie? Why had some of my favorite superb actors agreed to be in it? I soon enough found out. Near the end of the movie, both husband and I totally captivated, I demanded that he pause it: I was too pulled in and not ready for whatever the big reveal was about to be regarding one of these cardinals (and Isabella Rosellini, a nun to rival Meryl Streep's character in Judgment) . These characters are some of the best-drawn fictional clergy in movie history. When I was ready, I told my husband turn it back on. I instantly understood Christianne's enthusiastic reaction. My husband and I couldn't stop laughing joyously, just like her. We've decided to invite a bunch of our movie-loving friends to see "Conclave" at our house the evening after Christmas/Hanukah. Beautifully, masterfully contrived, filmed, directed, and acted. See it. Well worth our $19.99.

Not a thriller. Slowburn soap opera, well made drama that burns itself with an unearned twist at the the end. Artistically well crafted, acted, directed...but thematically contrived. When the Crying Game came out, it was edgy. If it was released today, it'd be expected. Not only are ubiquitous thematic ambitions missing the mark, but over the years empathy has turned to apathy and may soon turn to disdain. Movies should be made FOR you; not TO you. SPOILERS: If there was a creative basis for these themes, I would appreciate it. I'm not opposed to the theme itself. I don't even consider the theme political or sexual in it's nature. What I'm opposed to is it's contrived infusion into the script. Conclave is not bad because of politics (I happen to support individual liberty). It's bad because it's artistically lazy. It's bad because it does not fully optimize the actual story's potential. It's bad because you didn't even take the time to explain why you think this end would even be a good thing. It's bad because you don't even make a case on why you think it would be progress. It's bad because critics can't even condemn it artistically because they fear being confused with bigotry. So it's ultimately bad because it's going to get a RT score that it didn't really earn; but that it got through submission.

I believed virtually none of it: the characters were largely cardboard cutouts. The plot twists had the subtlety of an offstage explosion (I hope I'm not giving anything away). The heartfelt speech was a pale imitation of Shoes of the Fisherman. And as for the final catharsis -- listen: I'm Jewish, and I can't believe there is a semi-literate Catholic anywhere who could have believed it for a minute. Fiennes may rightfully win the Oscar, but not even a performance that good could redeem the screenplay. IN THE BEGINNING WAS THE WORD.

Conclave is a lovely visual experience. St√©phane Fontaine (cinematography), Suzie Davies (Production Design) and Roberta Federico (Art Direction) deserve accolades. The artistic beauty of this film reminds me of The Danish Girl and Brooklyn. Edward Berger directed the film. The cast is top notch: Ralph Fiennes, Stanley Tucci, John Lithgow, Sergio Castellitto, and Isabella Rossellini. The writers (Peter Straughan and Robert Harris) wrote excellent dialogue. They cleverly steered the audience in two directions toward the conclusion. The conversations include an unbiased scrutiny of opposing political views. When the one ending is apparent, I felt a little miffed by the logic and the editorializing. ‚ÄòYou, dear audience, must know that this is the way the world should work.‚Äô I thought the ending jumped the shark. Always blame the writers. ;) I‚Äôve never seen a movie I didn‚Äôt like, but I‚Äôve watched a thousand films I‚Äôll never watch again. I‚Äôll watch Conclave again because of the color, photography, and visual artistry. The cinematic experience is like revisiting my favorite art pieces at my local museum. If you like hagiographic topics, I recommend the TV mini-series The Young Pope with Jude Law and Diane Keaton, and The New Pope, the follow up mini-series with Jude Law and John Malkovitch. The 2019 film The Two Popes is an excellent look at Pope Benedict XVI (Anthony Hopkins) and Pope Francis (Jonathan Pryce).

"Conclave" (2024) offers a fascinating glimpse into the secretive world of the Vatican as cardinals gather to elect a new Pope. This political thriller masterfully weaves a tale of intrigue, ambition, and hidden agendas, keeping you captivated with its suspenseful plot and compelling characters. The film excels in its portrayal of the power dynamics and subtle manipulations that unfold within the confines of the conclave. The cardinals, each with their own beliefs and ambitions, engage in a delicate dance of alliances and betrayals as they strive to influence the outcome of the election. The performances are superb, with Ralph Fiennes delivering a standout performance as Cardinal Lomeli, a man of unwavering faith navigating the murky waters of Vatican politics. The supporting cast, including Stanley Tucci, John Lithgow, and Isabella Rossellini, adds depth and complexity to the narrative, creating a compelling ensemble of characters. The film's atmosphere is masterfully crafted, with the grandeur and solemnity of the Vatican setting enhancing the sense of intrigue and suspense. The pacing is deliberate, allowing for a gradual build-up of tension as the cardinals' deliberations unfold. While the film's ending may leave some viewers wanting a more definitive resolution, it effectively highlights the complexities and ambiguities inherent in the pursuit of power and faith. "Conclave" is a thought-provoking and suspenseful thriller that offers a rare glimpse into the inner workings of one of the world's most powerful institutions.

I wasn't expecting a great deal from Conclave, yet it all unfolds with such precision: an unlikely potboiler that Edward Berger presents not only thoughtfully, but viciously and deliciously. You'd think that being locked in a room with a gathering of elderly gentlemen deviously attempting to shaft each other wouldn't be a lot of fun. However, the whole thing is a blast from start to finish, presenting the secretive papal election as a high-stakes thriller, with the Catholic Cardinals manipulated like chess pieces by those who crave ultimate power. A deftly executed and gripping tale of secrets, lies and human ambition. Fiennes is at the top of his game, while the supporting cast conspires to wrap this tale of faith, power and morality in sumptuous dramatic cloth. The sometimes scandalous material is handled smoothly, without fuss, and the film's very restraint reads as a kind of moral intelligence, the final result is a high-camp gripper. Conclave packs so many twists, turns, ponders and scrutinises throughout its runtime that it's hard not to think of this as the world's most serious Carry-On film. A real sleeper hit.
